TWO
BETTER BROADCASTS NEWS LETTER
OCTOBER 1, 1953
Valuable Air Waves
In its “The Listener Speaks Again” the
San Francisco Branch of the AAUW pub¬
lishes the following under the heading So¬
cial Responsibility,
“The air waves over which all programs
are broadcast belong to us, the American
people. It follows logically, therefore, that
each of us should feel responsible for seeing
that these air waves are used to serve our
interests and needs, as well as those of our
families, our communities, and our nation.
“On the other hand, the local broadcaster
is required by law (Communications Act of
1934) to operate “in the public interest,
convenience, and necessity.” This is an
agreement which he must reaffirm periodi¬
cally when he applies for renewal, of his
license.
"When the broadcaster carries out this
responsibility to the people and when the
people become actively interested in the
way in which their air waves are used, then
we shall have better radio and television.”
News of TV Programs
ABC—TV
John Daly has been made vice-president
in charge of TV news for ABC. He will
also moderate “What's My Line?" and “It’s
News to Me.’’
A good block of programs early Sunday
evening: 6:30, America's Town Meeting;
7:00, The Greatest Story Ever Told; 7:30,
Four Square Court, a discussion of social
problems.
Cavalcade of America, Tues., 7:30 p.m.
Theater Guild, high ranking dramatic
series is on ABC Tues., 9:30 p.m.
At Issue is a new discussion program,
Sun., 9:00-9:15.
CBS—TV
Mrs. Emma Dixon Sheehe, associate pro¬
fessor of education at Columbia University,
and authority on child development, is to
have charge of a program on CBS for the
pre-school child Monday through Friday,
9:30 a.m., EST. That puts it immediately
before NBC’s Ding Dong School, which has
roused growing enthusiasm ever since
it started last fall. In other sections of the
country the time is likely to be different.
Life with Father has moved from New
York to the Coast. Fletcher Markle will
probably produce it.
Omnibus, late Sunday afternoon, will
again have Alistair Cooke as emcee. Each
show will be unified by a central theme.
Lamp unto My Feet, drama, is scheduled
for Sunday afternoon; also Man of the
Week, from Washington, D.C.
See It Now is scheduled for 10:30 p.m.;
Chronoscope, fifteen minutes of current his¬
tory, for 11:00 p.m. daily.
What in the World, a quiz on objects in
the University of Pennsylvania Museum,
Sun., 4:30 p.m.
Adventure, Sun. afternoon, in cooperation
with the American Museum of Natural
History.
DU MONT
Georgetown University Forum, 7 p.m.
Sun.
Johns Hopkins Science Reviews, 8 p.m.,
Wed.
Author Meets Critics, Thurs. 9:30 p.m.
are stimulating discussion periods.
Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, in “Life is Worth
Living” will return, October 13, as a spon¬
sored program over the largest linking of
TV stations to date—-132.
The Chicago Symphony will be presented
Wednesday at 8:30 EST.
In 1951 “Magic Cottage’’ got TV Guide's
Gold- Medal award as the best children's
show on television. It presents fairy tales,
from which the terrifying has been re¬
moved.
NBC—TV
Excursion, a new program for the 8-16-
year age group, Sunday, 3:30, was first
aired Sept. 13. Burgess Meredith is the Mas¬
ter of Ceremonies. It will feature adapta¬
tions of books for young people. It is pro¬
duced by the TV-Radio Workshop of the
Ford Foundation.
Other programs for children and young
people that have proved their interest: Ding
Dong School 10:00 a.m., Monday through
Friday; Carnival of Books, 9:30 a.m. Sunday
(also for ages 8-16. The time is sometimes
changed in local areas); Youth Wants to
Know (Sunday, 1:00 p.m. High school
students question government officials. It is
an intelligent program).
American Inventory, Sunday, 2 p.m., is a
new program produced in cooperation with
the Sloan Foundation.
Critic at Large (Leon Pearson) will re¬
turn Sundays, 3 p.m., in an adult resume
touching on literature, art, and the theater.
Reasons Why
Reasons why others like programs, and
why we like them, are illuminating—and
important. The following programs of news
and discussion were rated excellent by the
majority in the 1953 Look-Listen Project.
These were the chief reasons given:
Edward R. Murrow, 7:45 p.m., (EST)
CBS, “Always says whether what he says
is a fact or his own opinion.” “Reports all
important facts, uncolored by personal bias.
Each report means a statement by the of¬
ficial most closely connected with the hap¬
pening and often by an official in opposition.
Analysis, when given, is fair, logical, and
intelligent.” “I like his calm delivery.”
World News, Morgan Beatty, 7:30 p.m.
NBC, “Reports by several reporters.” “Quite
objective, though sometimes shows prefer¬
ences.” "Somewhat sensational manner of
delivery; otherwise good.” "I like his using
men on the spot. But must we always have
headlines?”
John Cameron Swayze, 7:45 p.m. NBC
"Excellent choice of events.” “Too Repub¬
lican.”
Erwin Canham, Tues., 9:45, ABC,
"Points out positive, constructive phases of
each side.”
Adverse comments on news programs:
“Stresses the sensational, and appears to
put emphasis on strife and prejudice.”
“Too many sensational or showy items.”
“Highly emotional—appeals to American¬
ism, Patriotism, etc.” “Strives for the thea-
atrical and sensational; dramatizes every
item.”
Town Meeting, Tues. 9:00, ABC, “Time¬
ly; gives different viewpoints.” “A thought-
awakener.”
Capitol Cloakroom, Fri. 10:05, CBS,
“Gives candid opinions of public figures.”
Northwestern Reviewing Stand, Sun.,
11:30 a.m., MBS, “Stimulating and informa¬
tive. Assertions were explained.”
Meet the Press, Sun. 10:00 p.m., NBC,
“Frankness and directness.” “Questions in¬
telligent, pertinent.” "Whole interview was
conducted courteously.”
What people want is easily discernible
from the reasons for their preferences.
The Look-Listen Project
Since the public domain of the air waves
is leased, free, to private groups who pro¬
mise to use them in “the public interest,”
it behooves the public to do some thinking
about what IS iN ITS INTEREST. The
thinking won’t get good programs unless it
is expressed. One person s opinion has less
influence with broadcasters than many
people’s. The Look-Listen Project is a
means whereby many citizens can express
their opinions at the same time.
Each person participating is asked to rate
eight radio or television network programs,
on one station, 3-10 p.m. and tell why he
so rated them. It is important that various
civic, religious, educational, and socially
minded groups present the project to their
members as something to help in. Radio
and television are shaping our nation, and
members will want to express their opinions
where they will count. The results of the
ratings and opinions will be sent to spon¬
sors, broadcasters, and the Federal Com¬
munications Commission.
The Look-Listen Project was- chosen, .by
the Council as the nation-wide effort on
which all would this year unite, because it
is already seven years old as sponsored by
the Wisconsin Association, and last year
had monitors in 16 states. Thus it has
proved itself useful in all parts of the
country.
It has also proved its influence. One sta¬
tion responded, “The entire programming
and management staff have read and re¬
read your letter”; another, “We have made
several changes in our programming, fol¬
lowing receipt of your past survey.” Na¬
tional sponsors say, “a very constructive
job,” “a remarkably fine job,” “The listen¬
er comments on all programs were highly
interesting,” etc.
Choosing a Month
Organizations may. choose any month,
October through March, as their Project
month. However, it is hoped that most
groups will choose a month before January
31. We want the 1954 Project Report to
be an effective voice of the Council; and
only returns reaching Headquarters by Jan.
31 can be included in it.
Send for your material early, please. The
direction sheet that goes to each participant
and report sheets for the chairman are
furnished free of charge; the cards, at cost
—3c for the eight cards each person needs.
Money will be refunded for unused cards
returned. So estimate the number of monitors
you will have optimistically. Send that
estimate and your check to Mrs. G. F.
Matthews, 4539 Winnequah Road, Madison,
Wisconsin.
Other Local Projects
In the Look-Listen Project, network pro¬
grams are monitored. It is the big united ef¬
fort of the year.
When it is finished, local communities
may want to follow it with a monitoring
of local programs or with other undertak¬
ings. It is hoped that local enterprises will
spring up and thrive, and that accounts of
them will be sent to Newsletter.
Young Members of the
Council
Though the majority of members of this
Council will undoubtedly be adults (college
students among them) high school students
are cordially invited to membership—as
individuals, as classes, as schools. There
is work for them to do.
